Blaschke products

Let D={z∈C∣∣z∣<1}\D = \set{z \in \C \mid \abs{z} < 1}D={z∈C∣∣z∣<1} and let A(D)\mathcal{A}\p{\D}A(D) be the space of functions holomorphic in D\DD and continuous D‾\cl{\D}D. Let

U={f∈A(D) | ∣f(z)∣=1 for all z∈∂D}.\mathcal{U} = \set{f \in \mathcal{A}\p{\D} \st \abs{f\p{z}} = 1 \text{ for all } z \in \partial\D}.U={f∈A(D)∣∣f(z)∣=1 for all z∈∂D}.

Show that f∈Uf \in \mathcal{U}f∈U if and only if fff is a finite Blaschke product,

f(z)=λ∏j=1Nz−aj1−aj‾z,f\p{z} = \lambda \prod_{j=1}^N \frac{z - a_j}{1 - \conj{a_j}z},f(z)=λj=1∏N​1−aj​​zz−aj​​,

for some aj∈Da_j \in \Daj​∈D, 1≤j≤N<∞1 \leq j \leq N < \infty1≤j≤N<∞ and ∣λ∣=1\abs{\lambda} = 1∣λ∣=1.
Solution.

If fff is a Blaschke product, then it's clear that f∈Uf \in \mathcal{U}f∈U. Conversely, suppose ∣f(z)∣=1\abs{f\p{z}} = 1∣f(z)∣=1 on ∂D\partial\D∂D and continuous on D‾\cl{\D}D. By uniform continuity, we see that fff does not vanish on a neighborhood of ∂D\partial\D∂D, so because fff only has finitely many zeroes a1,…,aNa_1, \ldots, a_Na1​,…,aN​. Let

B(z)=∏j=1Nz−aj1−aj‾zB\p{z} = \prod_{j=1}^N \frac{z - a_j}{1 - \conj{a_j}z}B(z)=j=1∏N​1−aj​​zz−aj​​

so that fB\frac{f}{B}Bf​ is non-zero. Thus, Bf\frac{B}{f}fB​ is holomorphic, so by the maximum principle applied to both fB\frac{f}{B}Bf​ and Bf\frac{B}{f}fB​, we see that ∣fB∣=1\abs{\frac{f}{B}} = 1∣∣​Bf​∣∣​=1 on D\DD. Thus, fB≡λ\frac{f}{B} \equiv \lambdaBf​≡λ with ∣λ∣=1\abs{\lambda} = 1∣λ∣=1, so

f(z)=λ∏j=1Nz−aj1−aj‾z,f\p{z} = \lambda \prod_{j=1}^N \frac{z - a_j}{1 - \conj{a_j}z},f(z)=λj=1∏N​1−aj​​zz−aj​​,

which was what we wanted to show.
